theoryText: The fan theory proposes that Sanji's inability to fight Mr. 2 while transformed into Nami reveals that his weakness isn't truly about chivalry or refusing to fight women. The evidence cited is that Mr. 2 Bon Clay is most certainly NOT a woman - an okama perhaps, but not a woman. Yet Sanji was completely paralyzed upon Mr. 2's transformation into Nami, while he had no problem smashing Usopp's face without hesitation. The theory concludes that the driving force behind Sanji's actions isn't his chivalry, but his libido - he can't fight pretty people who appear female, regardless of their actual gender. This distinction becomes important because it's not the fact that Sanji can't fight women, it's that he can't fight pretty ones.
author: Various fans on forums and discussion boards
platform: Arlong Park Forums / General Fan Discussion
supportingEvidence: Sanji had no hesitation attacking Usopp in earlier episodes
Mr. 2 is objectively not a woman but Sanji still couldn't attack
Sanji only froze when Mr. 2 took on Nami's attractive appearance
Later in the series (Enies Lobby), Sanji cannot fight Kalifa even with Robin's life at stake
counterEvidence: Sanji explicitly states his code is about never harming women
His principles were instilled by Zeff as part of chivalric ideals
The theory diminishes Sanji's character by making it about attraction rather than honor

theoryTitle: Mr. 2's Devil Fruit Combat Limitation Intentional Design
theoryText: Fans theorize that the Mane Mane no Mi's inability to allow proper combat techniques while transformed is an intentional balancing mechanism by Oda. If Mr. 2 could copy both appearance AND maintain his full Okama Kenpo mastery, the fruit would be too powerful for espionage and combat combined. The limitation forces users to choose between deception (staying transformed) or combat effectiveness (reverting to original form). This creates interesting tactical decisions in battle and prevents the fruit from being overpowered. The theory suggests this is why Mr. 2 developed such a strong martial arts style in the first place - to compensate for the times when he must fight in his true form.
author: One Piece power-scaling community
supportingEvidence: Episode 116 clearly shows Mr. 2 must revert to use techniques properly
The fruit is already extremely powerful for infiltration
Adding full combat capability while transformed would be unbalanced
Oda typically gives Devil Fruits creative limitations
counterEvidence: The limitation is never explicitly explained in-universe
Could simply be Mr. 2's personal fighting style incompatibility
Other Paramecia fruits don't show similar transformation-combat trade-offs

theoryTitle: The Fight Foreshadows Sanji's Enies Lobby Failure
theoryText: This theory posits that Episode 116's fight between Sanji and Mr. 2 intentionally foreshadows Sanji's critical failure at Enies Lobby against Kalifa. In Episode 116, Sanji wins despite his weakness being exploited because he finds a clever workaround (exploiting Mr. 2's transformation mechanics). However, this establishes that Sanji's chivalry can be weaponized against him. The theory suggests Oda planted this seed early to make Sanji's later complete inability to fight Kalifa more believable and tragic - showing that there are situations where no clever trick can overcome his fundamental principles. The progression from 'nearly defeated but finds a way' to 'completely defeated, no way out' demonstrates character consistency and raises the stakes for how this weakness impacts the crew.
author: Narrative analysis fans
supportingEvidence: Both fights exploit the same character weakness
Episode 116 shows the weakness CAN be overcome with tactics
Enies Lobby shows the weakness CANNOT always be overcome
Oda frequently plants long-term narrative seeds
counterEvidence: Could be coincidence rather than intentional foreshadowing
The fights are years apart in publication
Different circumstances (male transformed vs actual woman)

theoryTitle: Sanji Respecting Mr. 2 Sets Up Future Friendship
theoryText: Fans noted that Sanji's respectful treatment of Mr. 2 after defeating him ('Thanks for the good fight' and sparing him) was unusual and specific. This theory suggests this moment was intentionally written to establish mutual respect that would pay off in Impel Down when Mr. 2 sacrifices himself to help Luffy. The theory argues that small moments of honor between enemies in One Piece often foreshadow future alliances or redemption arcs. Sanji recognizing Mr. 2 as a worthy opponent and choosing mercy planted the seeds for Mr. 2's eventual heroic turn and the friendship between Mr. 2 and the Straw Hats.

supportingEvidence: Mr. 2 later helps the Straw Hats escape Arabasta
